name: Audrey
comment: This is a test

name: Rita Selin
comment: My own experience as a person exploring the ramifications of her own white privilege has made me aware that I need to confront this in myself.

name: Cory Cox
comment: It talks about racism in an open and non-confrontational way. This entire series is excellent - I intend to sit down and watch it with my children & grandchildren

name: Bill Conley
comment: I honestly think our diversity and videos like this have split us more as a country.  Instead of being a "melting pot" we've decided to focus on our differences.  The only constant similarity has been to blame white people.  I think white people are sick of being blamed, especially when they see people of other cultures having the same problems and the answer is to blame white people.

name: Randy
comment: it didn't include anyone who looked like me a white, lower class, middle aged blue collar worker.

name: John
comment: All live matter, not just black lives. Racism still exists, because people, and not just minorities, continue to beat a drum that does not need to be beat.  This is not meant to be racist, or condemning or to beat someone down.  As a white male, I don't care if someone is black, white, Hispanic, gay, straight, transgender, whatever.  What drives me nuts is when someone feels the need to push their agenda in my face or my family's face. I tend to my own business and i politely ask you do the same

name: Heather Harja
comment: I have not heard most of these terms before.  After reviewing most of the video comments, I feel a lot of what these individuals are reporting may simply be miscommunication or perceived "slights."  I feel that we as a society have gone too far in creating labels for literally everything.  You see it in the medical system; creating disease names for normal body reactions.  I think this creates divides and puts up defensive walls where there needn't be one.  Makes reaching out to you harder.

name: Doc
comment: ALL people are "colored." I have never met someone that did not have a "color." My Family is Ashkenazim Bavarian.

name: Cindy Etter
comment: it presented a wide range of opinions and reactions showing thought, compassion, and frustration.

name: George
comment: Being an old geezer, I like to "read the paper", not "watch the paper".  If you're a newspaper, please make it possible for me to read what you create.   I'em not into video or watching people talk.  Reading is faster.

name: David Krause
comment: "This fetish, weird thing that white people have with our hair." So, is proclaiming that "white people" have this thing with "our hair" a micro-aggression, too? I think so. Here's the problem with all of this b.s. No perspective. There are real issues that confront our country, and screaming about micro-aggression is trying to expand the problem in one direction - towards whites. Yes, there are issues, but as this demonstrates, racism/generalization is a two-way street. Human nature.

name: Don McDaniel
comment: As a child of 10 in a totally segregated Southern Illinois town  to being a member of a totally integrated Air Force as an adult.  We have had blacks now at the highest levels of government.  The problem is not institutional as such.  Rather, it is a problem of a poor educational system --- which does a disservice to all races.

name: Kathleen
comment: as a female, "white privilege" never applied to me. I resent it that people of color assume racism or privilege in me simply because of the color of my skin.

name: Tom
comment: To me the term"white Privilege" Is just some made up idea put forth to keep us all mad at each other. I live in a small town where i can say that everyone has the same chance in life regardless of the color of their skin. Racism will always exist. You can try to make sense of it but you will never eradicate it.

name: White Dude
comment: There is an increasingly collective need in society to make everyone equal. It's simply not reality, and it never will be. For everyone, education, wealth, manners, self respect and the ability to speak well, clearly and intelligently, differentiate us from one another.

name: ted wight
comment: Action, not words. Everyone is to some extent afraid of those different than they are. That cannot be erased since one looks at another and perceives differences. It should be accepted, acknowledged and discussed. After people get to know those different, most of them accept and many times enjoy those differences. Political parties exacerbate the divide purposely to gain and retain power, raw power over you and me.

name: Neil
comment: My experience with microagression is fairly limited. I have not had a chance to hear from people who have experienced it directly and it is eye opening. The people that shared 'it is about the people receiving it vs the intent' was helpful to hear.

name: Dan Pens
comment: Racism is like riding a bike in a gentle breeze. If you have a 10-15 mph wind at your back, you do not feel it. You have no sense that you are being helped by the breeze at your back. But if you ride INTO the wind, even a gentle 10-15 mph breeze, you FEEL it pushing against you, impeding your progress. This explains why many whites fail to recognize racism. They have never had to ride against the wind.

name: ted wight
comment: "White privilege" is a Democratic Progressive political party construct. Invented with many other words of emotion that divide this country into "tribes" each receiving and giving power. Certainly white people, especially males, have accomplished more for the country and its inhabitants than any other group. But that must be declared a lie by the Left in its quest for power. The need for inclusion and assimilation as "American" was the glue that kept the country together. Achievement, not privi

name: molly cruz
comment: hybrid people are better; just like mutts are better than breeds. Breeding and purity are myths, improve one feature and then just weaken the strains. Purity implies a vacuum and we know how Nature hates those!There are no pure people for any race. We out breed instinctively, as opposites seem to attract. That's Nature's idea too.

name: Cheryl
comment: Although I look white, I am not so 'white'. People of color have called me racist (in a mean way) because I look white and therefore benefit from 'white privilege'. It hurts me to not belong anywhere. Due to being in-between I can't sympathize with those who bemoan how hard it is to not be white, and I can't sympathize with those who cry about how hard it is to be white. If my life is a success, either camp will tell me it's not because I've done well for a myriad of reasons.

name: Nancy Barker
comment: I am so impressed with this unveiling of a long overdue discussion. Thank you so much. I would love more.

name: Dusty
comment: It pits one race against the other. Is it called "Asian Privilege" when the predominant race is Asian? No. Only in politically correct America is something like this intellectually contemplated. The problem is man's heart, and his refusal to except Jesus Christ into his heart. This is not a "social problem, therefore it will never be solved by less than spiritual understanding. This is a Heart condition, not a mind condition. God Bless

name: Winston
comment: People don't like people who are not like them. Sociology 101.

name: Mark
comment: the Seattle Times did NOT include close captioning for the deaf/and hard of hearing.  How can I follow what is being said?  Can we say: "Let's continue to marginalize communities even more by not providing accessibility against the deaf and hard of hearing." #hearingprivilege
notes: **We should follow up with him about the status of closed captioning

name: J. Yonker
comment:
I would first like to know how the "white population"
is classified?

name: Whitney
comment:
Dear Seattle,
I'm a Texan who has been living among you for the past few years. If you happen to meet me and ask me the question, "Where  are you originally from" and I tell you Texas, do yourself and me a favor and do not say "Oh, I'm sorry" or mention Austin. I am not sorry and you now look incredibly ignorant. I'll gladly talk to you about what Texas is like, the good and the bad. But if you stereotype me from the get go why even bother? You've clearly made up your mind about me.

name: Katherine Woo
comment: As a Korean American, I am profoundly disturbed by the movement of the mainstream media on race, pushing an antagonistic message on race derived from Critical Race Theory, a radical paradigm specifically created to challenge liberalism and evidence-based scholarship.  Obviously their is some residual racism in society, but little of it outside law enforcement is truly "institutional." Very few issues are as simple as fixating on white people and that is largely a meme to avoid self-criticism.

name: Karen Walker-Ward
comment: I agree that this topic needs to be discussed.  We need to develop an educational curriculum to start in elementary school to combat this issue.

name: Louiza Umtuch
comment: I always try to look at people as person not but what color they are.  They should be unbiased towards people who apply for jobs or play sports look at their talents and not a person of color.

name: Warren Stewart
comment: The term 'racist' today is going beyond just skin color.  I think groups are using the label to stifle free speech criticizing  particular ideologies.  Examples might be certain religious groups or those with sexual identities.  It can become a civil rights issue  and sometimes shuts off valid discussion.

name: bob
comment: COLOR BLINDNESS IS A REAL PROBLEM IN THIS COUNTRY.AND WE NEED TO FIX THAT PROBLEM.

name: Scott Flowers
comment: When I was younger I grew up in a diverse middle class neighborhood.  I didn't realize that race differences were highlighted in life.  It wasn't until they started teaching black history in school that it became apparent.  My parents never referred to someone as Black, Mexican, Jewish, or Asian.  They were referred by their names and what happened.  Obviously we see the differences between us and others, but that doesn't make us racist. A white man with red hair is nicknamed 'Rusty'.

name: Warren Stewart
comment: The US is predominately white so,  yes,  it seems on the surface like there is and has been white privilege.  If you go to Africa or Japan,  you would probably see "black privilege"  or "asian privilege".  Some of it is literally built in to a country.  In the US we have tried,  with certain laws,  to equal the playing field.  I think we have done that,  and possibly even tipped the other way. Young white males in the US are put behind many minorities for jobs,  scholarships,  etc.

name: R. Butler
comment: Yes. Black Lives Matter. Women's Lives Matter.  Children's Lives Matter. Asian Lives Matter. Speaking from experience, I have no problem discussing racism, bigotry, privilege entitlement, arrogance and superiority (political, religious and ethnic, etc.) because if we cannot communicate about our differences how can we come together as a community?

name: Warren Stewart
comment: I hear that diversity means including people from many different backgrounds,  races,  religions,  or other.  In practicality though,  it can mean stifling one group over another.  We have always had clubs or groups of like mindedness.  That is not bad necessarily.  Forcing a group to include others that create friction or hostility should not be required by law,  and we're moving toward that.  I'm thinking or the Boy Scouts or certain faith-based employers.

name: Ruth Anne Phillips
comment: I worked for the Lynchburg Fire Department and the racism and mysogyny there horrified me. When I research fire depts across the country, it appears to be endemic in the culture. Firelawblog.com highlights almost monthly lawsuits and filings, yet nothing is done to prevent it or change the culture. The fire departments appear to be untouchable. Even after a 98 million dollar settlement with the NYFD, you still have cases such as those in Chicago to stop the hiring of black female firfighters. SM
